title: Axios
text:
The big picture: Per Axios' Shane Savitsky, a major sticking point in negotiations has been the Irish backstop — which aims to prevent a hard border with customs controls between the EU member country Ireland and Northern Ireland, which is part of the U.K. It's the only land border the EU and U.K. would share.

AP reports that negotiators worked into the night Wednesday on regulations concerning customs and value-added tax (VAT), which would "regulate trade in goods" at the border.

What they're saying: The EU has prepared the legal text of a draft Brexit agreement ahead of the summit, reports the BBC, which notes that the British government "has yet to approve the documents" — and without the DUP's support, it could thwart any chance of Johnson reaching any kind of consensus in Brussels.

A spokeswoman for European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker tweeted that he had spoken with Johnson on Thursday morning.

"Every hour and minute counts" before the European Council summit, she said. "We want a deal."

Go deeper: Northern Ireland's Brexit balancing act

Editor's note: This article has been updated with new details throughout.
description: Smart, efficient news worthy of your time, attention, and trust
